During this era of COVID-19 and distance learning, we need to be vigilant about making sure our young people are safe online. We also need to be aware of those who are suffering from feelings of insecurity, self-doubt, and even suicide.

Some of you may be aware of a disturbing story about a man who live-streamed his suicide on Facebook. This video in question was also shared on Tik Tok and now, it has caused more concerns about how dangerous social media can be to our young people who are struggling with depression and suicidal ideation.

September is Suicide Awareness Month, and we want you to remember that counselors and special services in our district are available to assist those who might be struggling with feelings of insecurity and self-doubt. We also recommend referring to www.fresnocares.org for other valuable resources and services dedicated to helping those in need.

https://apnews.com/0cf6ea4e10ebe136beecbd079581337f

Due to COVID-19, children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school will receive extra food benefits (up to $365 per eligible child). Today, Juneteenth (a combination of June and 19), is an unofficial American holiday and an official Texas state holiday, celebrated annually in the United States to commemorate Union army general Gordon Granger's reading of federal orders in the city of Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, proclaiming all slaves in Texas were now free.

Here is an article for parents on how to explain the history and significance of Juneteenth to their children: https://www.parents.com/holiday/what-is-juneteenth-explaining-the-history-of-the-holiday-to-kids/

Today, Juneteenth (a combination of June and 19), is an unofficial American holiday and an official Texas state holiday, celebrated annually in the United States to commemorate Union army general Gordon Granger's reading of federal orders in the city of Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, proclaiming all slaves in Texas were now free.

Here is an article for parents on how to explain the history and significance of Juneteenth to their children: https://www.parents.com/holiday/what-is-juneteenth-explaining-the-history-of-the-holiday-to-kids/

Due to COVID-19, children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school will receive extra food benefits (up to $365 per eligible child). These food benefits are called Pandemic EBT or P-EBT benefits. P-EBT benefits help families in California buy food while schools are closed due to the COVID-19 emergency.

Families with children who get CalFresh, Medi-Cal or Foster Care benefits do NOT need to apply. Most families should have received their P-EBT card in the mail during the month of May.

Families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals and who do not get their P-EBT card in the mail, must apply online before June 30, 2020. The online application will be available starting May 22 at ca.p-ebt.org. For any questions, please call 877-328-9677

Due to COVID-19, children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school will receive extra food benefits (up to $365 per eligible child). These food benefits are called Pandemic EBT or P-EBT benefits. P-EBT benefits help families in California buy food while schools are closed due to the COVID-19 emergency.

Families with children who get CalFresh, Medi-Cal or Foster Care benefits do NOT need to apply. Most will get their P-EBT card in the mail during the month of May.

Families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals and who do not get their P-EBT card in the mail, must apply online before June 30, 2020. The online application will be available starting May 22 at ca.p-ebt.org. For any questions, please call 877-328-9677

This year, students from #RioVista attended the 73rd Annual California Family, Careers, and Community Leaders of America (FCCLA) Virtual State Leadership Conference, which was held in April. The theme of the 2020 conference, “Your Story,” inspires members to share their journey and leadership opportunities in FCCLA.

Rio Vista students placed first in the Central Valley region and first in California during the FCCLA Competitions. Miss Karkazian, FCCLA Advisor for the Rio Vista Chapter, worked with students, Melody Stetsko and Adela Cojocaru, as they tirelessly worked on their projects and enthusiastically prepared for the competitions.

President of the Rio Vista Chapter, Melody Stetsko, won first place in the regional competition titled “Room Design.” Adela Cojocaru took first place in the region and went on to win first place in the state competition; her event was titled “Repurpose and Redesign”.

We are proud to congratulate these talented students and their advisor for a job well done!

This week, Central Unified School District is celebrating all of our classified staff and departments.

This morning, we are proud to recognize our Assessments & Instructional Tech departments.

The assessment office is pivotal in coordinating and managing all district benchmarks, language proficiency exams, physical fitness tests, students, staff, parent surveys and state assessments. All of these are critical components that ensure Central USD students continue to achieve their goals.

And our instructional tech department supports the use of technology throughout our district. They provide support for the equipment, programs, and materials that support student learning on devices in the district. Instructional Tech has also played an integral role in providing families with the necessary tools and resources they need for online and distance learning while our schools remain closed.

So, to all of our classified and certificated staff in this department, we thank you for all of your efforts!

This week, Central Unified School District is celebrating all of our classified staff and various departments.

We begin by recognizing our Library Services staff.

Library services provide access to instructional materials for all of our students and build a love of reading and learning. Library staff offer storytime, book talks, maker space activities, and a safe place for all students.

Our elementary site libraries are staffed by a classified library media technician and at the secondary level, we also have credentialed, certificated Teacher Librarians.

Since the schools have closed, library staff has been at distribution sites checking out technology and resources for students every week. Our library staff is devoted to supporting both our students and staff and they are now preparing to collect both textbooks and library books at the end of the school year.

We thank all of you for everything you do!

Today, April 1st, is Census Day, a key reference date for the 2020 Census. This day is used to determine who is counted and where in the 2020 Census. When you respond, you'll tell the Census Bureau where you live as of April 1, 2020, and include everyone who usually lives and sleeps in your home. You can respond before or after today. We encourage you to respond as soon as you can.

Remember that we ALL need to be counted--this will determine how much funding we receive for services such as law enforcement, school districts, school meals, road construction/improvements, government representation, and much more!

Watch this very informative video on the Census 2020 and please share this information! Encourage your friends and neighbors to complete their Census 2020 forms. Our voices count!

Here's the link where you can complete the Census 2020 form online: https://my2020census.gov/?fbclid=IwAR0ELxvDkXjGHxNBC9MerM1WVH-LtS-GqqbHvb8uGB8GEldZ-uUXLWalGCU

Central Unified School District has some of the best art students anywhere in the Valley!

Last Thursday, at ArtHop, some of Shirley Yuen's art students from Central High School West campus were recognized for their artistic excellence at heARTbeat 2020!

heARTbeat is a showcase of student artwork from schools throughout Fresno County & sponsored by Fresno County Superintendent of Schools Jim Yovino.

Junior Arrianne Janelle Aguba Ortega won the Artistry Award for "Open Book". Arrianne also won the "People's Choice Award" with fellow artist Katie Baguinguito. And fellow artists Faith Vu & Whittney Ankney deserve props for their talents as well.

Congratulations to all of our talented, young artists!
